output: It is the constant angular size of the sun.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is the reflected radiance \\emphS\\(^(Sf)\\) separated?
output: It is separated into separate components for each surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the reflected radiance from surfaces?
output: \\beginequation S^\\rm(Sf) = \\sum\\limits_n S^\\rm(Sf n) \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the individual shading surface reflected radiances?
output: \\beginequation S^\\rm(Sf n)(\\bfp^\\rm(T)) = \\int\\limits_\\Omega ^\\rm(Sf n) \\mathop\\rm \\mathcalT\\nolimits (\\bfp^\\rm(T)\\bfp^\\rm(I))S^\\rm(Refl n)(\\bfp^\\rm(I)t)\\left(  - \\bfp^\\rm(I)\\cdot \\bfn \\right)d\\Omega ^\\rm(I) \\labeleq:SSfnpTEquation \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the solid angle of integration represent in the equation for individual shading surface reflected radiances?
output: It is subtended by the portion of the exterior reflecting surface \\emphn viewed by the fenestration; if one surface lies behind another the hidden part of its surface is removed from the solid angle it subtends.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the requirement for the solid angle \\(\\Omega ^\\rm(Sf)\\)?
output: \\beginequation \\beginarrayl\\Omega ^\\rm(Sf) = \\bigcup\\limits_n \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf n) \\\\\\bigcap\\limits_n \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf n) = 0\\endarray \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why is \\emphS\\(^(Refln)\\) time dependent?
output: Because the incident radiation on the surface depends on the sun position.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: When must Equation~\\refeq:SSkypTEquation be evaluated?
output: After the exterior surface shading or reflectance calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the requirement for the solid angles \\(\\Omega ^\\rm(Sky)\\) and \\(\\Omega ^\\rm(Sf)\\)?
output: \\beginequation \\Omega ^\\rm(Sky) \\cap \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf) = 0 \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the transmitted radiance from the ground-reflected exterior radiation?
output: \\beginequation S^\\rm(Gnd)(\\bfp^\\rm(T)) = \\int\\limits_\\Omega ^\\rm(Gnd) \\mathop\\rm \\mathcalT\\nolimits (\\bfp^\\rm(T)\\bfp^\\rm(I))S^\\rm(Gnd)(\\bfp^\\rm(I)t)\\left(  - \\bfp^\\rm(I)\\cdot \\bfn \\right)d\\Omega ^\\rm(I) \\labeleq:SGndpTEquation \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the requirement for the solid angles \\(\\Omega ^\\rm(Gnd)\\) and \\(\\Omega ^\\rm(Sf)\\)?
output: \\beginequation \\Omega ^\\rm(Gnd) \\cap \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf) = 0 \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why is \\emphS\\(^(Gnd)\\) time dependent?
output: Because the incident radiation on the ground may be affected by shading or reflection from exterior surfaces which is dependent on the sun position.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the discretized form of Equation~\\refeq:SSkypTEquation?
output: \\beginequation S_j^\\rm(TSky) = I^(\\bfSky)(t)\\sum\\limits_i \\in \\Omega ^\\rm(Sky) T_ji\\Lambda_iis_i \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is \\(s_i\\) in the context of the discretized equation?
output: \\beginequation s_i = s(\\bfp_i^\\rm(I)) \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is summarized by the requirement regarding the solid angle?
output: The requirement is that the solid angle it subtends is summarized by the union of the solid angles for each surface with no intersection between them.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the union of solid angles for each surface?
output: \\beginequation \\beginarrayl\\Omega ^\\rm(Sf) = \\bigcup\\limits_n \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf n) \\\\bigcap\\limits_n \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf n) = 0\\endarray \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why is \\emphS\\(^(Refln)\\) time dependent?
output: \\emphS\\(^(Refln)\\) is time dependent because the incident radiation on the surface depends on the sun position.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: When must Equation \\refeq:SSkypTEquation be evaluated?
output: Equation \\refeq:SSkypTEquation must be evaluated after the exterior surface shading or reflectance calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the requirement for the intersection of solid angles for the sky and surfaces?
output: \\beginequation \\Omega ^\\rm(Sky) \\cap \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf) = 0 \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the transmitted radiance from ground-reflected exterior radiation?
output: \\beginequation S^\\rm(Gnd)(\\bfp^\\rm(T)) = \\int\\limits_\\Omega ^\\rm(Gnd) \\mathop\\rm \\mathcalT\\nolimits (\\bfp^\\rm(T)\\bfp^\\rm(I))S^\\rm(Gnd)(\\bfp^\\rm(I)t)\\left(  - \\bfp^\\rm(I)\\cdot \\bfn \\right)d\\Omega ^\\rm(I) \\labeleq:SGndpTEquation \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What additional requirement is mentioned regarding the ground-reflected exterior radiation?
output: There is the requirement that \\(\\Omega ^\\rm(Gnd) \\cap \\Omega ^\\rm(Sf) = 0\\) and the incident radiation on the ground may be affected by shading or reflection from exterior surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why is \\emphS\\(^(Gnd)\\) time dependent?
output: \\emphS\\(^(Gnd)\\) is time dependent because it is dependent on the sun position as indicated in Equation \\refeq:SGndpTEquation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: How can Equation \\refeq:SSkypTEquation be rewritten using discretization?
output: \\beginequation S_j^\\rm(TSky) = I^(\\bfSky)(t)\\sum\\limits_i \\in \\Omega ^\\rm(Sky) T_ji\\Lambda_iis_i \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is \\(s_i\\) in the context of the rewritten equation?
output: \\beginequation s_i = s(\\bfp_i^\\rm(I)) \\endequation is the sky radiance shape factor evaluated at the central direction of the i\\(^th\\) solid angle bin.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the 'T' superscript denote in the equation for transmitted outgoing radiance?
output: The 'T' superscript denotes that \\emphS is the transmitted outgoing radiance due to incident sky radiation for the fenestration under discussion.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the stipulation \\(i \\in \\Omega ^\\rm(Sky)\\) on the summation mean?
output: The stipulation \\(i \\in \\Omega ^\\rm(Sky)\\) on the summation means that the sum is to include only those solid angle elements for which the sky is viewed by the fenestration.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is essentially a shading calculation in the context of the equation?
output: The stipulation to include only those solid angle elements for which the sky is viewed by the fenestration is essentially a shading calculation in addition to a restriction to downward-going incident directions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the sky geometric factor \\(V_i^(Sky)\\)?
output: \\beginequation V_i^(Sky) = \\left\\   \\beginarrayrl    1           & \\textall of  \\Delta\\Omega_i \\text views sky for all of fenestration \\\\    \\textviewed fraction & \\textsome of  \\Delta\\Omega_i \\text fenestration views sky \\\\    0           & \\textnone of  \\Delta\\Omega_i \\text views sky for any part of fenestration   \\endarray  \\right. \\labeleq:ViSkyEquation \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: How is the summation over all downward directions carried out?
output: \\beginequation  S_j^(TSky) = I^Sky(t)\\sum_i down T_ji \\Lambda_ii V_i^(Sky) s_i \\labeleq:SjTSkyEquation \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: How does Equation \\refeq:SSfnpTEquation change?
output: \\beginequation S_j^\\rm(T Sf n) = \\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Sf n)S^\\rm(Refl n)(\\bfp_i^\\rm(I)t) \\labeleq:SjTSfnEquation \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is \\(V_i^(Sf\\ n)\\)?
output: \\(V_i^(Sf\\ n)\\) is another geometric view factor defined analogously to Equation \\refeq:ViSkyEquation giving the fraction of the solid angle \\(\\Delta \\Omega_i\\) that views the exterior surface \\emphn.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the relationship between \\(V_i^\\rm(Sky)\\) and \\(V_i^\\rm(Sf n)\\)?
output: \\beginequation V_i^\\rm(Sky) + \\sum\\limits_\\rmn V_i^\\rm(Sf n) = 1 \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is \\(S^(Refln) (\\bfp_i^(I)t)\\) in the context?
output: The quantity \\(S^(Refln) (\\bfp_i^(I)t)\\) is the reflected radiance at a particular location on the n\\(^th\\) exterior surface --- the location where the direction \\textbf\\emphp\\emph\\(_i\\)\\(^(I)\\) intersects the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the 'T' superscript in the equation denote?
output: The 'T' superscript has been added on the left-hand side of the equation to denote that S is the transmitted outgoing radiance due to incident sky radiation for the fenestration under discussion.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the stipulation i ∈ Ω(Sky) mean in the summation?
output: The stipulation i ∈ Ω(Sky) means that the sum is to include only those solid angle elements for which the sky is viewed by the fenestration.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What kind of calculation is described in addition to a restriction to downward-going incident directions?
output: A shading calculation is described in addition to a restriction to downward-going incident directions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is anticipated by defining a sky geometric factor?
output: The result of the calculation is anticipated by defining a sky geometric factor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the sky geometric factor V_i^(Sky)?
output: The equation for the sky geometric factor V_i^(Sky) is: V_i^(Sky) = \\left\\ \\beginarrayrl 1 & \\textall of  \\Delta\\Omega_i \\text views sky for all of fenestration \\\\ \\textviewed fraction & \\textsome of  \\Delta\\Omega_i \\text fenestration views sky \\\\ 0 & \\textnone of  \\Delta\\Omega_i \\text views sky for any part of fenestration \\endarray \\right.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the next step after defining the sky geometric factor?
output: The next step is carrying out the summation over all downward directions and writing the equation for S_j^(TSky).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for S_j^(TSky)?
output: The equation for S_j^(TSky) is: S_j^(TSky) = I^Sky(t)\\sum_i down T_ji \\Lambda_ii V_i^(Sky) s_i

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does Equation~\\refeq:SSfnpTEquation become?
output: Equation~\\refeq:SSfnpTEquation becomes: S_j^(T Sf n) = \\sum\\limits_i down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)S^(Refl n)(\\bfp_i^(I)t)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for S_j^(T Sf n)?
output: The equation for S_j^(T Sf n) is: S_j^(T Sf n) = \\sum\\limits_i down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)S^(Refl n)(\\bfp_i^(I)t)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is V_i^(Sf n)?
output: V_i^(Sf n) is another geometric view factor defined analogously to Equation\\refeq:ViSkyEquation giving the fraction of the solid angle \\Delta \\Omega_i that views the exterior surface n.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation relating V_i^(Sky) and V_i^(Sf n)?
output: The equation relating V_i^(Sky) and V_i^(Sf n) is: V_i^(Sky) + \\sum\\limits_\\rmn V_i^(Sf n) = 1

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the quantity S^(Refln) (\\bfp_i^(I)t)?
output: The quantity S^(Refln) (\\bfp_i^(I)t) is the reflected radiance at a particular location on the n^th exterior surface where the direction \\textbf\\emphp\\emph_i^(I) intersects the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is assumed about the surface reflectance?
output: The surface is assumed to have either a diffuse reflectance \\rho^(n) or a specular reflectance \\rho^(sp n). EnergyPlus assumes that an exterior surface is either diffusing or specular but not both.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Is the reflectance uniform over the surface?
output: Yes the reflectance is assumed uniform over the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is denoted by E_i^n?
output: E_i^n denotes the incident irradiance of the surface n.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the incident irradiance E_i^n independent of?
output: The incident irradiance E_i^n pertains only to the surface n and is independent of the fenestration or its basis.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is important if the EnergyPlus shading calculations were modified?
output: If the EnergyPlus shading calculations were modified to relax the assumption of uniform incident irradiance on exterior surfaces it would become important that the irradiance pertains only to those surfaces n that are viewed by the solid angle element i.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are specularly reflecting surfaces defined?
output: For specularly reflecting surfaces definitions include identifying the sun direction s(t) and the specular reflection direction r(t) within the set of basis solid angles \\Delta \\Omega_i.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is E_i r(t)^(Dn)?
output: E_i r(t)^(Dn) is the contingent direct beam irradiance non-zero only if i = r(t) where i is the specularly reflected direction for the surface n.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What assumption is made about the surface's reflectance?
output: The surface is assumed to have either a diffuse reflectance ρ^(n) or a specular reflectance ρ^(spn). EnergyPlus assumes that an exterior surface is either diffusing or specular but not both.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is assumed about the reflectance over the surface?
output: The reflectance is assumed uniform over the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is the incident irradiance of surface n denoted?
output: The incident irradiance of the surface n is denoted by E_i^n.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the subscript 'i' in the irradiance E_i^n signify?
output: The subscript 'i' signifies that the irradiance pertains to the portion of the surface that is viewed by the solid angle element ΔΩ_i of the fenestration f.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What definitions are made for specularly reflecting surfaces?
output: For specularly reflecting surfaces within the set of basis solid angles ΔΩ_i s(t) identifies the one containing the sun direction at time t and r(t) identifies the one containing the specular reflection direction of the sun at time t.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the contingent direct beam irradiance denoted by?
output: The contingent direct beam irradiance is denoted by E_i r(t)^(Dn).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: When is the contingent direct beam irradiance E_i r(t)^(Dn) non-zero?
output: The contingent direct beam irradiance is non-zero only if i = r(t) meaning i is the specularly reflected direction for the surface n.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the specularly reflected irradiance S^(Refln)?
output: S^(Refl n)(\bfp_i^(I)t) = \rho ^(sp n)E_i r(t)^(Dn) + \rho ^(n)E_i^n

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What are the normalized irradiance factors U defined for?
output: The normalized irradiance factors U are defined as E_i^n = U_i^(Skyn)I^(Sky)(t) + U_i Sun(tsh)^(Dn)I^(D)(t) and E_i r(t)^(Dn) = U_i r(t)^(Dn)I^(D)(t).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the rewritten equation for S^(Refln) using normalized irradiance factors?
output: S^(Refln)(\bfp_i^(I)t) = I^(D)(t) U_i r(t)^(Dn) \rho^(spn) + I^(D)(t) U_i Sun(tsh)^(Dn) \rho^(n) + I^(sky)(t) U_i^(Skyn) \rho^(n)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for S_j^(T Sf n) in terms of the incident irradiances?
output: S_j^(T Sf n) = \sum\limits_i down T_ji\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)\left( \rho^(sp n)E_i r(t)^(Dn) + \rho^(n)E_i^n \right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for S_j^(T Sf n) in terms of the normalized irradiance factors?
output: S_j^(T Sf n) = \sum\limits_i down T_ji\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)I^(D)(t)U_i r(t)^(Dn)\rho^(sp n) + \sum\limits_i down T_ji\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)\left[ I^(D)(t)U_i Sun(tsh)^(Dn)\rho^(n) + I^(Sky)(t)U_i^(Skyn)\rho^(n) \right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for S_j^(T Sf n) when the specularly reflected term is removed from the sum?
output: S_j^(T Sf n) = T_j r(t)\Lambda_r(t) r(t)V_r(t)^(Sf n)E_r(t) r(t)^(Dn)\rho^(sp n)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the irradiance in terms of reflection and normalized factors?
output: n)(\\bfp_i^\\rm(I)t) = \\rho ^\\rm(sp n)E_i\\rm r(t)^(Dn) + \\rho ^\\rm(n)E_i^n

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are normalized irradiance factors defined?
output: Normalized irradiance factors \\emphU are defined by \(E_i^n = U_i^(Skyn)I^(Sky)(t) + U_i\\rm Sun(tsh)^(Dn)I^(D)(t)\) ~and \(E_i\\rm r(t)^(Dn) = U_i\\rm r(t)^(Dn)I^(D)(t)\)  where \(U_i\\rm Sun(tsh)^(Dn)\) ~denotes the fraction of the beam solar that irradiates the surface for a given sun direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the purpose of the notation \\emphSun(tsh)?
output: It is evaluated during the shading calculation as indicated by the notation \\emphSun(tsh).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the rewritten equation for irradiance considering the normalized factors?
output: S^(Refln)(\\bfp_i^(I)t) =  I^(D)(t) U_i r(t)^(Dn) \\rho^(spn) +  I^(D)(t) U_i Sun(tsh)^(Dn) \\rho^(n) +  I^(sky)(t) U_i^(Skyn) \\rho^(n)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: How does Equation~\\refeq:SjTSfnEquation transform in terms of incident irradiances?
output: S_j^\\rm(T Sf n) = \\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Sf n)\\left( \\rho ^\\rm(sp n)E_i\\rm r(t)^(Dn) + \\rho ^\\rm(n)E_i^n \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: How is the equation expressed in terms of normalized irradiance factors?
output: S_j^\\rm(T Sf n) = \\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Sf n)I^\\rm(D)(t)U_i\\rm r(t\\rm)^\\rm(Dn)\\rho ^\\rm(sp n) + \\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Sf n)\\left[ I^\\rm(D)(t)U_i\\rm Sun(tsh)^\\rm(Dn)\\rho ^\\rm(n) + I^(Sky)(t)U_i^\\rm(Skyn)\\rho ^\\rm(n) \\right]

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why can the specularly reflected term be removed from the sum?
output: The specularly reflected term can be removed from the sum since only one value of i can contribute.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for separating specular and diffuse reflectance?
output: S_j^\\rm(T Sf n) = T_j\\rm r(t\\rm)\\Lambda_\\rm r(t\\rm) r(t\\rm)V_\\rm r(t\\rm)^\\rm(Sf n)E_\\rm r(t\\rm) r(t\\rm)^\\rm(Dn)\\rho ^\\rm(sp n) + \\rho ^\\rm(n)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Sf n)E_i^n

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for separating specular and diffuse reflectance in terms of normalized factors?
output: S_j^\\rm(T Sf n) = T_j\\rm r(t\\rm)\\Lambda_\\rm r(t\\rm) r(t\\rm)V_\\rm r(t\\rm)^\\rm(Sf n)U_\\rm r(t\\rm) r(t\\rm)^\\rm(Dn)I^(D)(t)\\rho ^\\rm(sp n) + \\rho ^\\rm(n)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Sf n)\\left( I^\\rm(D)(t)U_i\\rm Sun(tsh)^\\rm(Dn) + U_i^(Skyn)I^(Sky)(t) \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are exterior reveal surfaces treated with respect to shading and reflection?
output: With respect to shading and reflection of exterior radiation into the fenestration the exterior reveal surfaces can be treated as additional diffusely reflecting exterior surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is ground radiation treated?
output: Ground radiation is treated in the same way as radiation reflected from interior surfaces except that one sums only over upward-going incident directions and the ground is assumed to be diffusely reflecting.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the transmitted radiance from ground reflectance?
output: S_j^\\rm(T Gnd) = \\rho ^\\rm(Gnd)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm up T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Gnd)E_i^(Gnd)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the symbol \\(E_i^(Gnd)\\) represent?
output: In this equation the symbol \\(E_i^(Gnd)\\) ~is shorthand for a spatial calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the solid angle region \\(\\Delta \\Omega_i\\) view?
output: The solid angle region \\(\\Delta \\Omega_i\\) ~views (from various points over the fenestration area) some spatial region of the ground.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the symbol \\(E_i^(Gnd)\\) denote?
output: The symbol \\(E_i^(Gnd)\\) ~denotes the incident irradiance on the ground over this spatial region.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is ground irradiance calculated in the absence of shading?
output: In the absence of shading this would be simply \\(I^(G) = I^(Sky) + I^(D)\\cos \\theta_Sun\\) ; shading requires a more complex calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What method does the EnergyPlus code use for ground radiation calculation?
output: Currently the EnergyPlus code does a Monte-Carlo calculation: rays are randomly generated from the window when they strike the ground a calculation is made to determine whether that point receives direct solar radiation and what portion of the sky it views.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for separating specular and diffuse reflectance from the exterior surfaces?
output: S_j^(T Sf n) = T_j\rm r(t\rm)\Lambda_\rm r(t\rm) r(t\rm)V_\rm r(t\rm)^(Sf n)U_\rm r(t\rm) r(t\rm)^(Dn)I^(D)(t)\\rho ^(sp n) + \\rho ^(n)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)\\left( I^(D)(t)U_i\\rm Sun(tsh)^(Dn) + U_i^(Skyn)I^(Sky)(t) \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are the exterior reveal surfaces treated with respect to shading and reflection of exterior radiation into the fenestration?
output: The exterior reveal surfaces can be treated as additional diffusely reflecting exterior surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is ground radiation treated in comparison to radiation reflected from interior surfaces?
output: Ground radiation is treated in the same way as radiation reflected from interior surfaces except that one sums only over upward-going incident directions and the ground is assumed to be diffusely reflecting.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the transmitted radiance from ground reflectance?
output: S_j^(T Gnd) = \\rho ^(Gnd)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm up T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Gnd)E_i^(Gnd)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the symbol \(E_i^(Gnd)\) shorthand for?
output: The symbol \(E_i^(Gnd)\) is shorthand for a spatial calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the solid angle region \(\Delta \Omega_i\) view?
output: The solid angle region \(\Delta \Omega_i\) views some spatial region of the ground from various points over the fenestration area.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(E_i^(Gnd)\) in the absence of shading?
output: In the absence of shading \(E_i^(Gnd) = I^(G) = I^(Sky) + I^(D)\\cos \\theta_Sun\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How does the EnergyPlus code currently calculate shading?
output: The EnergyPlus code does a Monte-Carlo calculation: rays are randomly generated from the window when they strike the ground a calculation is made to determine whether that point receives direct solar radiation and what portion of the sky it views.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for \(E_i^(Gnd)\) with shading?
output: E_i^(Gnd) = U_i\\rm Sun(tsh)^(DGnd)I^(D)(t) + U_i^(SkyGnd)I^(Sky)(t)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the transmitted radiance from direct beam radiation?
output: S_j^(T Sun) = T_j\\rm s(t)\\cos \\theta ^(Sun)I^(D)(t)V_i\\rm s(t\\rm)^(D)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the significance of the geometric view factor \(V_i s(t)^(D)\) in the equation for transmitted radiance from direct beam radiation?
output: The geometric view factor \(V_i s(t)^(D)\) is zero if the sun direction s(t) is not i; if i = s(t) it is the fraction of the fenestration area irradiated by the direct sun.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus treat the sun and circumsolar region in the context of transmitted radiance?
output: EnergyPlus treats the sun and circumsolar region as a point source.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is the calculation for each region of the ground viewed by a basis solid angle element performed?
output: The calculation is performed for each region of the ground viewed by a basis solid angle element instead of generating random rays from the window.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the notation \(E_i^(Gnd)\) represent?
output: The notation \(E_i^(Gnd)\) represents the results of the calculation where the U's are average viewing factors for the sun and sky calculated as part of the shading calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the transmitted radiance from the ground?
output: S_j^\\rm(T Gnd) = \\rho ^\\rm(Gnd)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm up T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Gnd)\\left( U_i\\rm Sun(tsh)^(DGnd)I^(D)(t) + U_i^(SkyGnd)I^(Sky)(t) \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is the transmitted radiance from direct beam radiation expressed?
output: The transmitted radiance from direct beam radiation is expressed as: \(S_j^(T Sun) = T_j s(t)\\cos \\theta ^(Sun)I^(D)(t)V_i s(t)^(D)\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the transmitted radiance from direct beam radiation?
output: S_j^\\rm(T Sun) = T_j\\rm s(t)\\cos \\theta ^\\rm(Sun)I^\\rm(D)(t)V_i\\rm s(t\\rm)^\\rm(D)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the geometric view factor \(V_i s(t)^(D)\) represent?
output: The geometric view factor \(V_i s(t)^(D)\) is zero if the sun direction s(t) is not i; if i = s(t) it is the fraction of the fenestration area irradiated by the direct sun.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why is there an absence of the sky correction in Equation~\\refeq:SSunpTEquation?
output: There is an absence of the sky correction in Equation~\\refeq:SSunpTEquation because EnergyPlus treats the sun and circumsolar region as a point source.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What have we developed expressions for at this point in the document?
output: We have developed separate expressions for a fenestration's transmitted radiance in a particular direction depending on the exterior source of the radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What do these expressions utilize?
output: These expressions utilize the discretized BTDF of the fenestration in the form of transmittance matrix elements over an angular basis.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is the exterior geometry re-expressed?
output: The exterior geometry is re-expressed in the form of geometric view factors in this basis.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What has the explicit time dependence of the exterior radiation been reduced to?
output: The explicit time dependence of the exterior radiation has been reduced to the time-varying direct and diffuse solar intensities and the solar position.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the time dependence of the solar position consist of?
output: The time dependence of the solar position consists merely in specifying for a particular time which of the basis solid angle elements contains the solar direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What can be pre-calculated for the fenestration transmittance calculation?
output: The entire exterior geometry necessary for the fenestration transmittance calculation can therefore be pre-calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the starting point for the interior calculations?
output: We begin with the discretized form of Equation~\\refeq:E2pTdA2Equation in which we also modify the surface notation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are the surfaces involved in the equation termed?
output: In that equation the surfaces involved are termed (1) and (2) where radiation is outgoing from surface 1 and incoming to surface 2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the notation used for the inner surface of the fenestration?
output: Here radiation is outgoing from the inner surface of the fenestration so we label that surface (f).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are the receiving surfaces labeled?
output: The receiving surface is one of the surfaces of the zone in which the fenestration is located. We number those surfaces with the index k so the receiving surface is labeled (k).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the power leaving the fenestration surface in direction j?
output: dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = E^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfp_j^\\rm(T))dA^\\rm(k\\rm) = S_j^\\rm(T) \\cdot \\left( \\bfn^\\rm(f) \\cdot \\bfp_j^\\rm(T) \\right)\\Delta \\Omega_j^\\rm(T)dA^\\rm(f)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the expression \\(\\left(\\bfn^(f)\\cdot\\bfp_j^(T)\\right) \\Delta\\Omega^(T)\\) simplify to?
output: The expression simplifies to \\(\\Lambda_jj^(T)\\) (where the superscript T is retained in case the incoming and outgoing bases are defined differently).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the alternative expression for the power leaving the fenestration surface in direction j?
output: dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = E^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfp_j^\\rm(T))dA^\\rm(k\\rm) = S_j^\\rm(T)\\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)dA^\\rm(f)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What do we obtain by integrating the expression over the fenestration area?
output: By integrating the expression over the fenestration area \\(A^(f)\\) we obtain the total power leaving the fenestration surface in direction j.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why might not all of the power reach surface k?
output: Not all of that power may reach surface k because some may strike the inner window reveal or a different zone surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What can be reduced to the time-varying direct and diffuse solar intensities and the solar position?
output: The entire exterior geometry necessary for the fenestration transmittance calculation can be reduced to the time-varying direct and diffuse solar intensities and the solar position.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the time dependence of the solar position specify?
output: The time dependence of the solar position specifies for a particular time which of the basis solid angle elements contains the solar direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What can be pre-calculated for the fenestration transmittance calculation?
output: The entire exterior geometry necessary for the fenestration transmittance calculation can be pre-calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the discretized form of Equation~\\refeq:E2pTdA2Equation modify?
output: The discretized form of Equation~\\refeq:E2pTdA2Equation modifies the surface notation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are the surfaces involved in Equation~\\refeq:E2pTdA2Equation termed?
output: The surfaces involved are termed (1) and (2) where radiation is outgoing from surface 1 and incoming to surface 2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Which surface is labeled (f) in the context of the fenestration?
output: The inner surface of the fenestration is labeled (f).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How are the receiving surfaces numbered?
output: The receiving surfaces are numbered with the index \\emphk so the receiving surface is labeled (\\emphk).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the discretized form of Equation~\\refeq:E2pTdA2Equation?
output: \\( dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = E^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfp_j^\\rm(T))dA^\\rm(k\\rm) = S_j^\\rm(T) \\cdot \\left( \\bfn^\\rm(f) \\cdot \\bfp_j^\\rm(T) \\right)\\Delta \\Omega_j^\\rm(T)dA^\\rm(f) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the expression for \\(\\left(\\bfn^(f)\\cdot\\bfp_j^(T)\\right) \\Delta\\Omega^(T)\\)?
output: \\(\\left(\\bfn^(f)\\cdot\\bfp_j^(T)\\right) \\Delta\\Omega^(T) = \\Lambda_jj^(T)\\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the modified form of the equation noting \\(\\Lambda_jj^(T)\\)?
output: \\( dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = E^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfp_j^\\rm(T))dA^\\rm(k\\rm) = S_j^\\rm(T)\\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)dA^\\rm(f) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What do we obtain by integrating over the fenestration area \\emphA\\(^(f)\\)?
output: We obtain the total power leaving the fenestration surface in direction \\emphj; however all of that power may not reach surface \\emphk.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What might happen to some of the power leaving the fenestration surface?
output: Some of the power may strike the inner window reveal or a different zone surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the definition of the spatial projection operator?
output: \\( \\bfx^\\rm(k\\rm) = \\mathop\\rm \\mathcalP\\nolimits ^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfp_j^\\rm(T)\\bfx^\\rm(f)) \\equiv \\mathop\\rm \\mathcalP\\nolimits_j^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfx^\\rm(f)) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Where is \\textbf\\emphx\\(^(k)\\) located?
output: \\textbf\\emphx\\(^(k)\\) is in the plane of surface \\emphk.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: How is the geometric form factor defined?
output: \\( F_j^\\rm(k\\rm) = \\frac1A^\\rm(f)\\int\\limits_\\mathop\\rm \\mathcalP\\nolimits_j^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfx^\\rm(f)) \\in A^\\rm(k\\rm) dA^\\rm(f) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for \\(dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm)\\) with the geometric form factor?
output: \\( dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = S_j^\\rm(T)\\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)A^\\rm(f) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the total power leaving the fenestration and arriving at surface \\emphk?
output: \\( W_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = \\sum\\limits_j S_j^\\rm(T)\\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)A^\\rm(f) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does substituting various equations into Equation~\\refeq:WjftokEquation yield?
output: Substituting various equations into Equation~\\refeq:WjftokEquation yields a series of expressions for the total power arriving at surface \\emphk from each of the sources of exterior radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What do the equations for transmitted radiation describe?
output: The equations for transmitted radiation describe an infinitesimal region meaning that the radiation in a given direction will always come from one source.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What problem is encountered when integrating the transmitted power over the fenestration surface?
output: The problem encountered is that for a given direction different parts of the fenestration area may receive radiation from different sources.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What might happen when projecting a receiving surface back onto the fenestration?
output: The projection of a receiving surface back onto the fenestration may produce an image that covers only part of the fenestration area and this image may not be identical with the part of the area that receives incident radiation from a particular source.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation representing the plane of surface k in terms of geometric form factors?
output: \\bfx^\\rm(k\\rm) = \\mathop\\rm \\mathcalP\\nolimits ^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfp_j^\\rm(T)\\bfx^\\rm(f)) \\equiv \\mathop\\rm \\mathcalP\\nolimits_j^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfx^\\rm(f))

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Where is \\textbf\\emphx\\(^(k)\\) located?
output: \\textbf\\emphx\\(^(k)\\) is in the plane of surface \\emphk.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the geometric form factor F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)?
output: F_j^\\rm(k\\rm) = \\frac1A^\\rm(f)\\int\\limits_\\mathop\\rm \\mathcalP\\nolimits_j^\\rm(k\\rm)(\\bfx^\\rm(f)) \\in A^\\rm(k\\rm) dA^\\rm(f)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the expression for dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm)?
output: dW_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = S_j^\\rm(T)\\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)A^\\rm(f)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the total power leaving the fenestration and arriving at surface \\emphk represent?
output: The total power leaving the fenestration (in any direction) and arriving at surface \\emphk is represented by the equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for W_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm)?
output: W_j^\\rm(f \\to k\\rm) = \\sum\\limits_j S_j^\\rm(T)\\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)A^\\rm(f)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What happens when substituting Equations~\\refeq:SSunpTEquation~\\refeq:SjTSkyEquation~\\refeq:SjTSfnidownEquation and~\\refeq:SjTGndEquation into Equation~\\refeq:WjftokEquation?
output: It yields a series of expressions for the total power arriving at surface \\emphk (by transmission through fenestration f) from each of the sources of exterior radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What do the equations for transmitted radiation describe?
output: The equations for transmitted radiation describe an infinitesimal region meaning that the radiation in a given direction will always come from one source.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What problem is encountered when integrating the transmitted power over the fenestration surface?
output: The problem is that for a given direction different parts of the fenestration area may receive radiation from different sources.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What issue arises with the projection of a receiving surface back onto the fenestration?
output: The projection may produce an image that covers only part of the fenestration area and this image may not be identical with the part of the area that receives incident radiation from a particular source.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the most important origin of the problem with radiation integration?
output: The existence of inner and outer window reveals as illustrated in Figure~\\reffig:mismatch-of-irradiated-and-viewed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure~\\reffig:mismatch-of-irradiated-and-viewed illustrate?
output: Mismatch of irradiated and viewed fenestration areas for different incident and outgoing directions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the portion of the fenestration area not viewed by the plane of surface \\emphk indicate?
output: It is instead viewed by one or more of the inner window reveals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What happens to the portion of the fenestration not irradiated in the figure?
output: It is in fact irradiated by diffusely reflected radiation from the outer window reveals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How can the issue with the fenestration area be accounted for in the equations?
output: By replacing the area \\emphA\\(^(f)\\) in Equation~\\refeq:WjftokEquation with the overlap area \\(A_ji^\\rm(f Src) k\\) (dark shaded in the figure) where \Src stands for the source of the incident radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation defining the overlap area \\(A_ji^\\left( fSrc \\right)k\\)?
output: A_ji^\\left( fSrc \\right)k = \\left. A_i^\\left( fSrc \\right) \\right|A_j^\\left( f \\right)k

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the total power at the interior surface \\emphk for each source of radiation become?
output: The total power at the interior surface \\emphk for each source of radiation is represented by the equation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total power at the interior surface \\emphk from the sky radiation source?
output: W^\\rm(Sky) k = I^(\\bfSky)(t)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^\\rm(Sky)A_ji^\\rm(f Sky) ks_i

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total power at the interior surface \\emphk from the solar fenestration normal source?
output: W^\\rm(Sfn)k = I^\\rm(D)(t)\\rho ^\\rm(sp n)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)T_j\\rm r(t\\rm)\\Lambda_\\rm r(t\\rm) r(t\\rm)V_\\rm r(t\\rm)^\\rm(Sf n)A_j\\rm r(t\\rm)^\\rm(f Sf n) kU_\\rm r(t\\rm) s(t\\rm)^\\rm(Dn) + I^(D)(t)\\rho ^\\rm(n)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^\\rm(T)F_j^\\rm(k\\rm)\\sum\\limits_i\\rm

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What is the most important origin of the problem discussed?
output: The most important origin of this problem is the existence of inner and outer window reveals as illustrated in Figure 93.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure 93 illustrate?
output: Figure 93 illustrates the mismatch of irradiated and viewed fenestration areas for different incident and outgoing directions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the figure show about the fenestration area viewed by the plane of surface k?
output: In the figure the portion of the fenestration area not viewed by the plane of surface k is instead viewed by one or more of the inner window reveals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How is the portion of the fenestration not irradiated in the figure actually irradiated?
output: The portion of the fenestration not irradiated in the figure is in fact irradiated by diffusely reflected radiation from the outer window reveals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How can we account for the mismatch in irradiated and viewed fenestration areas?
output: We can account for this by replacing the area A^(f) in Equation 93 with the overlap area A_ji^(f Src) k where 'Src' stands for the source of the incident radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the overlap area A_ji^(f Src) k?
output: A_ji^(f Src) k = \\left. A_i^(f Src) \\right|A_j^(f) k

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the total power at the interior surface k for each source of radiation become?
output: The total power at the interior surface k for each source of radiation becomes a series of equations representing different sources such as Sky Sfn Gnd and Sun.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total power from the sky at the interior surface k?
output: W^(Sky) k = I^(Sky)(t)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^(T)F_j^(k)\\sum\\limits_i down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sky)A_ji^(f Sky) ks_i

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total power from the Sfn at the interior surface k?
output: W^(Sfn)k = I^(D)(t)\\rho ^(sp n)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^(T)F_j^(k)T_j r(t)\\Lambda_r(t) r(t)V_r(t)^(Sf n)A_j r(t)^(f Sf n) kU_r(t) s(t)^(Dn) + I^(D)(t)\\rho ^(n)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^(T)F_j^(k)\\sum\\limits_i down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)A_ji^(f Sf n) kU_i Sun(tsh)^(Dn)  + I^(Sky)(t)\\rho ^(n)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^(T)F_j^(k)\\sum\\limits_i down T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Sf n)A_ji^(f Sf n) kU_i^(Skyn)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total power from the ground at the interior surface k?
output: W^(Gnd)k = I^(D)(t)\\rho ^(Gnd)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^(T)F_j^(k)\\sum\\limits_i up T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Gnd)A_ji^(f Gnd) kU_i Sky(tch)^(D Gnd)  + I^(Sky)(t)\\rho ^(Gnd)\\sum\\limits_j \\Lambda_jj^(T)F_j^(k)\\sum\\limits_i up T_ji\\Lambda_iiV_i^(Gnd)A_ji^(f Gnd) kU_i^(SkyGnd)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total power from the sun at the interior surface k?
output: W^(Sun)k = I^(D)(t)\\sum\\limits_j F_j^(k)\\Lambda_jj^(T)T_j s(t)\\cos \\theta_s(t)^(Sun)V_i s(t)^(D)A_j s(t)^(f Sun) k

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: How do we define solar irradiation factors Z?
output: Solar irradiation factors Z are defined as the fraction of the radiation incident on the fenestration due to a given exterior radiation source that is ultimately incident on the interior surface k.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation
input: What is the equation for the solar irradiation factor Z^(Sky) k?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why is the notation s(t) time dependent?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What happens if no basis element for the fenestration contains the sun at a given time?
output: If no basis element for the fenestration contains the sun at a given time then the corresponding view factor—and therefore irradiance or absorption factor—is zero.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: Why is it necessary to tabulate quantities with an s(t) subscript for all basis directions s?
output: It is necessary to tabulate those quantities with an s(t) subscript for all basis directions s that could possibly contain the sun direction to ensure accurate calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Calculation Module -> text
input: What does the specular direction r(t) depend on?
output: In equation the specular direction r(t) is uniquely determined by the sun direction s(t) so the Z factor does not need an additional index for s.

output: In the worst case (west-facing) one only needs to consider around 50 of these with much fewer needed in other orientations.

input: Why is it necessary to know the energy absorbed in each layer of the fenestration for thermal calculations?
