instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the different form of Equation~\\refeq:IGULGiDeflection?
output: 0 = L_\\left( i \\right) - L_G\\left( i \\right) + L_D\\left( i \\right)max - L_D\\left( i + 1 \\right)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the developed form of the equation for i=1?
output: 0 = L_\\left( 1 \\right) - L_G\\left( 1 \\right) + L_D\\left( 1 \\right)max - L_D\\left( 2 \\right)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the developed form of the equation for i=2?
output: 0 = L_\\left( 2 \\right) - L_G\\left( 2 \\right) + L_D\\left( 2 \\right)max - L_D\\left( 3 \\right)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the developed form of the equation for a general i?
output: 0 = L_\\left( i \\right) - L_G\\left( i \\right) + L_D\\left( i \\right)max - L_D\\left( i + 1 \\right)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the developed form of the equation for i=n-1?
output: 0 = L_\\left( n - 1 \\right) - L_G\\left( n - 1 \\right) + L_D\\left( n - 1 \\right)max - L_D\\left( n \\right)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What procedure is needed to express each L_D(i)max and its dependence on L_D(n)max?
output: In order to express each L_D(i)max and its dependence on L_D(n)max (deflection of inside/last pane) we will need to make the sum from first to last then from second to last third to last and so on.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for L_D(1)max?
output: L_D\\left( 1 \\right)max = \\mathop \\sum \\limits_k = 1^k = n - 1 \\left( L_G\\left( k \\right) - L_\\left( k \\right) \\right) + L_D\\left( n \\right)max \\labeleq:IGULD1max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for L_D(2)max?
output: L_D\\left( 2 \\right)max = \\mathop \\sum \\limits_k = 2^k = n - 1 \\left( L_G\\left( k \\right) - L_\\left( k \\right) \\right) + L_D\\left( n \\right)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for L_D(i)max?
output: L_D\\left( i \\right)max = \\mathop \\sum \\limits_k = i^k = n - 1 \\left( L_G\\left( k \\right) - L_\\left( k \\right) \\right) + L_D\\left( n \\right)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for L_D(n-1)max?
output: L_D\\left( n - 1 \\right)max = \\mathop \\sum \\limits_k = n - 1^k = n - 1 \\left( L_G\\left( k \\right) - L_\\left( k \\right) \\right) + L_D\\left( n \\right)max \\labeleq:IGULDn-1max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the next step after expressing each L_D(i)max?
output: Now substituting this set of equations back into Equation~\\refeq:IGUSumDiLDiEq0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the resulting equation after substitution?
output: \\mathop \\sum \\limits_i = 1^n - 1 D_\\left( i \\right)\\cdot \\left( \\mathop \\sum \\limits_k = i^k = n - 1 \\left( L_G\\left( k \\right) - L_\\left( k \\right) \\right) + L_D\\left( n \\right)max \\right) + D_\\left( n \\right)\\cdot L_D\\left( n \\right)max = 0

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation that relates L(2) L_G(2) L_D(2)max and L_D(3)max?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How can each L_D(i)max be expressed in terms of L_D(n)max?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for L_D(1)max?
output: L_D(1)max = ∑(k=1 to n-1) (L_G(k) - L(k)) + L_D(n)max

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the result of solving for L_D(n)max?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation

output: L_D(n)max = (∑(i=1 to n-1) (D(i)·∑(k=i to n-1) (L(k) - L_G(k)))) / (∑(i=1 to n) D(i))

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Equivalent Layer Fenestration Model -> text
input: What is described in the section titled 'Equivalent Layer Fenestration Model'?
output: The section describes the equivalent layer fenestration optical and thermal model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Equivalent Layer Fenestration Model -> text
input: What types of attachments can the Equivalent Layer fenestration model have?
output: The Equivalent Layer fenestration model can have four types of attachments: drapes venetian blinds roller blinds and insect screens.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Equivalent Layer Fenestration Model -> text
input: How are shading layers assumed to be represented in the Equivalent Layer fenestration model?
output: In this model shading layers are assumed to be uniform and can be represented by an equivalent homogeneous layer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the primary subject of the section titled 'Equivalent Layer Fenestration Model'?
output: The section describes the equivalent layer fenestration optical and thermal model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What types of attachments can the Equivalent Layer fenestration model have?
output: The Equivalent Layer fenestration model can have four types of attachments: drapes venetian blinds roller blinds and insect screens.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are shading layers represented in the equivalent layer fenestration model?
output: In this model shading layers are assumed to be uniform and can be represented by an equivalent homogeneous layer that has spatially-averaged 'effective' optical and thermal properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How can venetian blinds be characterized in the equivalent layer fenestration model?
output: Venetian blinds can be characterized using effective optical and thermal properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What happens to solar radiation when it strikes a window surface in the context of shading layers?
output: Some fraction of the incident solar radiation passes unobstructed through openings in a shading layer and the remaining fraction is intercepted by the structure of the layer. The intercepted radiation is partly absorbed partly reflected and partly transmitted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are the reflected and transmitted components of scattered solar radiation assumed to behave?
output: These reflected and transmitted components of the scattered solar radiation are assumed to be uniformly diffuse.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is a general property of shading layers regarding longwave radiation?
output: Shading layers because of their openness generally transmit longwave radiation and the effective infrared properties of shades account for that.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How does the equivalent layer approach handle multi-layer systems?
output: Using effective optical properties and a beam/diffuse split of solar radiation at each layer the equivalent layer approach can represent multi-layer systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What flexibility does the equivalent layer approach provide?
output: This representation provides virtually unlimited flexibility to combine different types of shading layers in a fenestration.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What data is required for the equivalent layer window model to characterize a particular layer?
output: The equivalent layer window model requires a few sets of optical data to characterize a particular layer and this set of data is used to calculate effective layer properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How can the effective solar optical properties of a venetian blind be calculated?
output: The effective solar optical properties of a venetian blind can be calculated as a function of slats optical properties and geometry.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is possible regarding slat angle in the equivalent layer fenestration model?
output: It is possible to adjust the slat angle at each time step in response to the changing angular position of the sun.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What control strategies does the model provide?
output: The model provides control strategies as a function of slat angle that can be changed at each time step as needed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are effective properties of a pleated drape calculated?
output: Effective properties of a pleated drape are calculated as a function of fabric properties and a specified value of fullness.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What input data is needed to fully characterize drapery fabrics roller blinds and insect screens?
output: The only input data needed to fully characterize drapery fabrics roller blinds and insect screens are material openness as area fraction and the transmittance and reflectance at normal incidence.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the shade openness area fraction equivalent to?
output: Shade openness area fraction is the same as the beam-beam transmittance at normal incidence.

input: What is the role of effective optical and thermal properties in characterizing venetian blinds?
output: Venetian blinds can be characterized using effective optical and thermal properties.

input: What happens to the intercepted radiation?
output: The intercepted radiation is partly absorbed partly reflected and partly transmitted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is each layer separated in multilayer fenestration?
output: In multilayer fenestration each layer is separated by a gap.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is a gap defined in the equivalent layer model?
output: A gap in the equivalent layer model is defined by specifying the fill gas and the gap spacing.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What gas types are currently allowed in the equivalent layer model?
output: Currently five gas types are allowed: Air Argon Xenon Krypton and Custom.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is the convective heat transfer coefficient in a gap calculated?
output: The convective heat transfer coefficient in a gap is calculated depending on the spacing the temperatures of the layers and the fill gas properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the equivalent-layer concept offer?
output: The equivalent-layer concept offers a wide range of multiple glazing and shading layers combination and can simulate multi-layer complex fenestration systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are the effective layer properties of venetian blinds pleated drapes roller blinds and insect screens calculated?
output: The effective layer properties of venetian blinds pleated drapes roller blinds and insect screens are calculated from geometric layer models and material properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What was developed under ASHRAE research project (ASHRAE 1311-RP)?
output: A set of empirical correlations for estimating off-normal material properties was developed under ASHRAE research project (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the equivalent layer window model support?
output: The equivalent layer window model supports many layers of glazing and shade combination in any order but does not support WindowShadingControl.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the venetian blind model of the equivalent layer window model provide?
output: The venetian blind model of the equivalent layer window model provides three types of blind slat angle control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is the equivalent layer windows system treated?
output: The equivalent layer windows system is treated as a series of parallel layers separated by gaps.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the first step in the equivalent layer fenestration model's two-step analysis?
output: The first step is determining the flux of absorbed solar radiation at each layer S_i caused by the incident radiation flux I_sol using net radiation analysis.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is a gap defined in the equivalent layer model?
output: A gap in the equivalent layer model is defined by specifying the fill gas and the gap spacing.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What gas types are currently allowed in the equivalent layer model?
output: Currently five gas types are allowed: Air Argon Xenon Krypton and Custom.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is the convective heat transfer coefficient in a gap calculated?
output: The convective heat transfer coefficient in a gap is calculated depending on the spacing the temperatures of the layers and the fill gas properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the equivalent-layer concept offer?
output: The equivalent-layer concept offers a wide range of multiple glazing and shading layers combination and can simulate multi-layer complex fenestration systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are the effective layer properties of different shading systems calculated?
output: The effective layer properties of venetian blinds pleated drapes roller blinds and insect screens are calculated from geometric layer models and material properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What research project developed empirical correlations for estimating off-normal material properties?
output: A set of empirical correlations for estimating off-normal material properties were developed under ASHRAE research project (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the equivalent layer window model support?
output: The equivalent layer window model supports many layers of glazing and shade combination in any order but does not support WindowShadingControl.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the venetian blind model of the equivalent layer window model provide?
output: The venetian blind model of the equivalent layer window model provides three types of blind slat angle control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is the equivalent layer windows system treated?
output: The equivalent layer windows system is treated as a series of parallel layers separated by gaps as shown in Figure 113.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure 113 illustrate?
output: Figure 113 illustrates the multi-layer fenestration analysis structure (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What analysis does the equivalent layer fenestration model use?
output: Equivalent layer fenestration model uses two-step analysis.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is determined in the first step of the equivalent layer fenestration model analysis?
output: In the first step the flux of absorbed solar radiation at each layer S\(_i\) caused by the incident radiation flux I\(_sol\) is determined using net radiation analysis.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is applied in the second step of the equivalent layer fenestration model analysis?
output: In the second step an energy balance is applied at each layer accounting for heat transfer and the known set of absorbed solar radiations S\(_i\) values in order to solve for the set of layer temperatures T\(_i\) and the corresponding heat fluxes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the fenestration model account for in the longwave radiant exchange?
output: The fenestration model accounts for the diathermanous shade layers in the longwave radiant exchange.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is glass considered with respect to longwave radiation?
output: Glass is considered opaque with respect to longwave radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the basis of the multilayer optical model?
output: The multilayer optical model is based on an algorithm originally developed by Edwards (1977) and extended by Wright and Kotey (2006).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the algorithm model in the multilayer optical model?
output: The algorithm models the interaction of incident solar radiation with a glazing system composed of any number of parallel planar specular glazing layers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How do shading layers interact with incident solar radiation in the model?
output: The shading layers scatter a portion of the incident solar radiation diffusely and the model tracks the beam and diffuse components of solar radiation as they interact with a multi-layer system of glazing and shading layers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure 114 illustrate?
output: Figure 114 illustrates the solar analysis of the multi-layer glazing/shading system showing beam and diffuse fluxes (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the beam and diffuse characterization of solar radiation demand?
output: The beam and diffuse characterization of solar radiation demands an expanded set of solar optical properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the purpose of the absorbed solar radiations S\(_i\) values?
output: The absorbed solar radiations S\(_i\) values are used to solve for the set of layer temperatures T\(_i\) and the corresponding heat fluxes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How does the fenestration model account for diathermanous shade layers?
output: The fenestration model accounts for diathermanous shade layers in the longwave radiant exchange.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is glass treated with respect to longwave radiation?
output: Glass is considered opaque with respect to longwave radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the basis of the multilayer optical model?
output: The multilayer optical model is based on an algorithm originally developed by Edwards (1977) and extended by Wright and Kotey (2006).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the algorithm model in the multilayer optical model?
output: The algorithm models the interaction of incident solar radiation with a glazing system composed of any number of parallel planar specular glazing layers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How do shading layers affect incident solar radiation?
output: The shading layers scatter a portion of the incident solar radiation diffusely.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the model track in the interaction of solar radiation?
output: The model tracks the beam and diffuse components of solar radiation as they interact with a multi-layer system of glazing and shading layers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is illustrated in Figure 114?
output: Figure 114 illustrates the conceptual arrangement for tracking beam and diffuse solar flux components.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the analysis of solar flux components yield?
output: The analysis yields beam-beam beam-diffuse and diffuse-diffuse fluxes providing full detail concerning the quantities of reflected transmitted and absorbed radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does Figure 115 show?
output: Figure 115 shows the quantities of interest for a single layer in terms of solar optical properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What are the expanded set of solar optical properties required for?
output: The beam and diffuse characterization of solar radiation demands an expanded set of solar optical properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What solar properties are required for each glazing or shading layer?
output: Each glazing or shading layer in general requires eleven sets of solar properties.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: Which properties are needed for common glazing layers?
output: Only beam-beam properties are needed for common glazing layers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are shading layers represented in the model?
output: Each shading layer is represented by a few sets of component properties and geometries that are converted to the full set of layer optical and thermal properties by equivalent layer models.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How do the models account for off-normal incidence of solar radiation?
output: The models account for off-normal incidence of solar radiation and can calculate the diffuse component from normal incidence values using numerical integration.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the thermal emissivity of a glazing or a shading layer represented by?
output: The thermal emissivity of a glazing or a shading layer is represented by the symbol \\( \\varepsilon \\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the symbol \\( \\theta \\) represent?
output: The symbol \\( \\theta \\) represents the incident angle measured in degrees.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the symbol \\( \\phi \\) stand for?
output: The symbol \\( \\phi \\) stands for the slat angle measured in degrees.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the meaning of the symbol \\( \\Omega \\)?
output: The symbol \\( \\Omega \\) represents the profile angle measured in degrees.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is represented by the symbol \\( J \\)?
output: The symbol \\( J \\) represents the radiosity of a layer surface measured in W/m².

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the symbol \\( T \\) denote?
output: The symbol \\( T \\) denotes the temperature of a layer measured in degrees Celsius.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the subscript \\( f \\) indicate?
output: The subscript \\( f \\) indicates the front side of a layer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the subscript \\( b \\) signify?
output: The subscript \\( b \\) signifies the back side of a layer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is represented by the subscript \\( bb \\)?
output: The subscript \\( bb \\) represents a beam-beam optical property which is a fraction of the beam radiation incident at a given layer and leaves the layer without being scattered.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the subscript \\( bd \\) denote?
output: The subscript \\( bd \\) denotes a beam-diffuse optical property representing a fraction of the beam radiation incident at a given layer that leaves the layer diffusely.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the subscript \\( dd \\) stand for?
output: The subscript \\( dd \\) stands for a diffuse-diffuse optical property representing diffuse radiation incident at a given layer that leaves the layer as diffuse.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the subscript \\( i \\) indicate?
output: The subscript \\( i \\) indicates the layer index.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the superscript \\( m \\) represent?
output: The superscript \\( m \\) represents a material property such as fabric material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is indicated by the superscript \\( str \\)?
output: The superscript \\( str \\) indicates an apparent material structure property of roller blinds.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the superscript \\( w \\) denote?
output: The superscript \\( w \\) denotes an apparent wire property.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is depicted in Figure 115?
output: Figure 115 depicts the twelve solar properties assigned at each layer (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How many sets of solar properties are generally required for each glazing or shading layer?
output: Each glazing or shading layer generally requires eleven sets of solar properties (Wright and Kotey 2006).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What solar properties are needed for common glazing layers?
output: Only beam-beam properties are needed for common glazing layers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is each shading layer represented?
output: Each shading layer is represented by a few sets of component properties and geometries that are converted to the full set of layer optical and thermal properties by equivalent layer models (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What do the models account for in solar radiation?
output: The models account for off-normal incidence of solar radiation and can calculate the diffuse component from normal incidence values using numerical integration.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is applied at each layer in the Equivalent Layer Thermal Model?
output: A surface energy balance is applied at each layer in the Equivalent Layer Thermal Model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is solved for in the Equivalent Layer Thermal Model?
output: The resulting set of equations is solved for layer temperatures and heat transfer fluxes in the Equivalent Layer Thermal Model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is shown in Figure 116?
output: Figure 116 shows the radiosity model used in thermal analysis of the multi-layer glazing/shading system (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the net radiation formulation use as a solution technique?
output: The net radiation formulation uses the radiosities Jfi and Jbi the radiant flux leaving the front and back surfaces of the i\\(^th\\) layer respectively as a solution technique.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How can the net radiant heat flux across a gap be expressed?
output: The net radiant heat flux across a gap can be expressed as the difference between the radiosities of the bounding surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the net radiation model analysis yield?
output: The net radiation model analysis yields the layer temperatures and corresponding heat transfer coefficients that are used to determine U-factor and SHGC.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: Where is the thermal analysis done?
output: The thermal analysis is done in the \ASHWAT_Thermal\ routine.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Glazing Layer Analysis -> text
input: What does the Equivalent-Layer window model allow?
output: The Equivalent-Layer window model allows a wide range of options regarding the selection of glazing layers and gaps combinations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Glazing Layer Analysis -> text
input: What can be mixed in the Equivalent-Layer window model?
output: The Equivalent-Layer window model allows mixing glazing and shading layers in any sequence.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Glazing Layer Analysis -> text
input: What example is given for layer placement in the Equivalent-Layer window model?
output: An example given is placing a venetian blind or a roller blind in between glazing layers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Glazing Layer Analysis -> text
input: What properties are required for common glazing types?
output: Only beam-beam solar properties at normal incidence infrared transmittance and infrared emissivity are required for common glazing types.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Glazing Layer Analysis -> text
input: How are off-normal solar properties estimated?
output: Off-normal solar properties at a given sun position are estimated by adjusting the normal incidence values in the \ASHWAT_OffNormalProperties\ routine.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Glazing Layer Analysis -> text
input: What assumption does the model make regarding transmittance?
output: The model assumes that the ratio between normal and off-normal transmittance is the same for the glazing layer in question and a reference piece.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is applied at each layer in the equivalent layer thermal model?
output: A surface energy balance is applied at each layer and the resulting set of equation is solved for layer temperatures and heat transfer fluxes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is depicted in Figure 116?
output: A schematic drawing of the multi-layer illustration and variables designation is shown in Figure 116 which is the radiosity model used in thermal analysis of the multi-layer glazing/shading system (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the net radiation formulation based on in the equivalent layer thermal model?
output: The net radiation formulation is based on the radiosities Jfi and Jbi the radiant flux leaving the front and back surfaces of the i-th layer respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is the net radiant heat flux across a gap expressed?
output: The net radiant heat flux across a gap can be expressed as the difference between the radiosities of the bounding surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the net radiation model analysis yield?
output: The net radiation model analysis yields the layer temperatures and corresponding heat transfer coefficients that are used to determine U-factor and SHGC.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: Where is the thermal analysis done in the equivalent layer thermal model?
output: The thermal analysis is done in 'ASHWAT_Thermal' routine.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What options does the Equivalent-Layer window model allow?
output: The Equivalent-Layer window model allows a wide range of options regarding the selection of glazing layers and gaps combinations and allows mixing glazing and shading layers in any sequence.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What properties are required for common glazing types in the Equivalent-Layer window model?
output: Only beam-beam solar properties at normal incidence infrared transmittance and infrared emissivity are required for common glazing types.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are off-normal solar properties estimated in the Equivalent-Layer window model?
output: Off-normal solar properties at a given sun position are estimated by adjusting the normal incidence values in 'ASHWAT_OffNormalProperties' routine.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is assumed about the ratio between normal and off-normal transmittance in the model?
output: The model assumes that the ratio between normal and off-normal transmittance is the same for the glazing layer in question and a reference piece of uncoated 6 mm glass with a moderate tint (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What types of gaps can be specified in the Gap Layer Analysis?
output: Gaps can be specified as sealed vented indoors or vented outdoors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is a sealed gap considered in the model?
output: The sealed gap is considered as an enclosed cavity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What assumption is made about air flow in the vented gap model?
output: The vented gap model assumes that air flow at the perimeter of the window is not restricted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What can be specified by molecular mass and thermo-physical properties in the model?
output: Any fill gas can be specified by molecular mass and thermo-physical properties of viscosity specific heat and thermal conductivity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How is the property 'p' evaluated in the model?
output: The property 'p' is evaluated using the quadratic equation of the form p = a + bT + cT^2 where T(K) is temperature and p is the property being evaluated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What built-in data does EnergyPlus have available?
output: EnergyPlus has built-in data available for common fill gas components including Air Argon Krypton and Xenon.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How do users specify CUSTOM gas in EnergyPlus?
output: Users specify CUSTOM gas by defining the coefficients as an input.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the equivalent layer fenestration model include for shading layer types?
output: The equivalent layer fenestration model includes a complete set of solar and longwave models for the four shading layer types: drapes venetian blinds roller blinds and insect screens developed under ASHRAE 1311-RP.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What models are used to evaluate the off-normal properties of drape roller blind and insect screen materials?
output: Semi-empirical models are used to evaluate the off-normal properties of drape roller blind and insect screen materials.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are the effective layer properties of venetian blinds and the effect of pleating in drapes determined?
output: The effective layer properties of venetian blinds and the effect of pleating in drapes are determined using a more fundamental net radiation scheme.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What do the openness fraction and beam-beam solar transmittance at normal incidence represent?
output: The openness fraction Ao and beam-beam solar transmittance at normal incidence τbb (θ = 0) really represent a geometric quantity and it has been confirmed that they can be used interchangeably (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the definition of openness in the equivalent layer fenestration model?
output: Openness is simply the fraction of a material by area that is open.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is used to convert solar reflectance from normal to off-normal?
output: A similar procedure is used to convert solar reflectance from normal to off-normal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: What types of gaps can be specified in the gap layer analysis?
output: Gaps can be specified as sealed vented indoors or vented outdoors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: How is a sealed gap considered in the gap layer analysis?
output: The sealed gap is considered as enclosed cavity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: When can vented gaps be specified?
output: Vented gaps is specified for inner and outer most gaps only and when the gas type is AIR.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: What assumption is made about air flow in the vented gap model?
output: The vented gap model assumes that air flow at the perimeter of the window is not restricted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: How can any fill gas be specified?
output: Any fill gas can be specified by molecular mass and thermo-physical properties of viscosity specific heat and thermal conductivity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: How are the thermo-physical properties of a fill gas evaluated?
output: This is done by providing 'a' 'b' and 'c' coefficients of the quadratic equation of the form p = a + bT + cT² where T(K) is temperature and p is the property being evaluated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: What built-in data is available in EnergyPlus for fill gas components?
output: EnergyPlus has built-in data available for common fill gas components including Air Argon Krypton and Xenon.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Gap Layer Analysis -> text
input: How do users specify a custom gas?
output: Users specify CUSTOM gas by defining the coefficients as an input.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: What types of shading layer types are included in the equivalent layer fenestration model?
output: Equivalent layer fenestration model has a complete set of solar and longwave models for the four shading layer types: drapes venetian blinds roller blinds and insect screens developed under ASHRAE 1311-RP.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: What models are used to evaluate the off-normal properties of drape roller blind and insect screen materials?
output: Semi-empirical models are used to evaluate the off-normal properties of drape roller blind and insect screen materials.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: How are the effective layer properties of venetian blinds and the effect of pleating in drapes determined?
output: The effective layer properties of venetian blinds and the effect of pleating in drapes are determined using a more fundamental net radiation scheme.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: What do the openness fraction and beam-beam solar transmittance at normal incidence represent?
output: The openness fraction A_o and beam-beam solar transmittance at normal incidence τ_bb (θ = 0) really represent a geometric quantity and it has been confirmed that they can be used interchangeably (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: What is openness?
output: Openness is simply the fraction of a material by area that is open.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: What properties are required to characterize drapery fabric roller blind and insect screen material in the equivalent layer fenestration model?
output: In equivalent layer fenestration model beam-beam transmittance at normal incidence (i.e. openness fraction) beam-diffuse transmittance and reflectance at normal incidence are required to characterize drapery fabric roller blind and insect screen material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: How can a conventional venetian blind in the equivalent layer model be characterized?
output: A conventional venetian blind in equivalent layer model can be characterized by specifying the geometry solar reflectance and transmittance and emissivity of the slats.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: How were the off-normal solar properties of drape roller blind and insect screen materials formulated?
output: The off-normal solar properties of drape roller blind and insect screen materials were formulated based on measurements (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: How can the longwave properties of drape fabrics roller blinds and insect screens be calculated?
output: The longwave properties of the drape fabrics roller blinds and insect screens can be calculated from the material emissivity and openness of the fabric (ASHRE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Shade Layer Analysis -> text
input: Who presented the optical model development for venetian blinds?
output: The optical model development for venetian blinds is presented by Yahoda and Wright (2004 and 2005) and Kotey et al. (2008).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Drapes and Curtains -> text
input: How are the off-normal optical properties of drapery fabric determined?
output: The off-normal optical properties of drapery fabric is determined from user specified optical properties at normal incidence (θ = 0) using empirical correlations (Kotey et al. 2009a).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Drapes and Curtains -> text
input: What input data is required to characterize drapery fabric?
output: The input data required to characterize drapery fabric are the beam-beam transmittance of the material at normal incidence τ_bb (θ = 0) = Ao the beam-diffuse transmittance of the material at normal incidence τ_bd (θ = 0) and the beam-diffuse (total) reflectance of the material ρ_bt (θ = 0).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Drapes and Curtains -> equation
input: What is the equation for off-normal transmittance?
output: τ_bb^m(θ) = τ_bb^m(θ = 0) · cos^b(θ)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Drapes and Curtains -> equation
input: What is the equation for off-normal total transmittance?
output: τ_bt^m(θ) = τ_bt^m(θ = 0) · cos^b(θ)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Drapes and Curtains -> equation
input: What is the equation for the variable b?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What materials are required to characterize in the context of drapery fabric roller blind and insect screen?
output: The materials required to characterize are drapery fabric roller blind and insect screen material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How can a conventional venetian blind in an equivalent layer model be characterized?
output: It can be characterized by specifying the geometry solar reflectance and transmittance and emissivity of the slats.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: On what basis were the off-normal solar properties of drape roller blind and insect screen materials formulated?
output: They were formulated based on measurements (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How can the longwave properties of drape fabrics roller blinds and insect screens be calculated?
output: They can be calculated from the material emissivity and openness of the fabric (ASHRE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: Who presented the optical model development for venetian blinds?
output: The optical model development for venetian blinds is presented by Yahoda and Wright (2004 and 2005) and Kotey et al. (2008).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are the off-normal optical properties of drapery fabric determined?
output: They are determined from user specified optical properties at normal incidence ($\\theta = 0$) using empirical correlations (Kotey et al. 2009a).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What input data are required to characterize drapery fabric?
output: The input data required are the beam-beam transmittance of the material at normal incidence $\\tau$\\(_bb\\) ($\\theta = 0$) = Ao the beam-diffuse transmittance of the material at normal incidence $\\tau$\\(_bd\\) ($\\theta = 0$) and the beam-diffuse (total) reflectance of the material $\\rho$\\(_bt\\) ($\\theta = 0$).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for off-normal beam-beam transmittance?
output: \\rm\\tau _\\rmbb^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\tau _\\rmbb^\\rmm\\rm(\\theta  = \\rm0) \\cdot \\rmco\\rms^\\rmb\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for off-normal beam-total transmittance?
output: \\rm\\tau _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\tau _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\rm(\\theta  = \\rm0) \\cdot \\rmco\\rms^\\rmb\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for parameter b in terms of beam-beam transmittance?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for parameter b in terms of beam-total transmittance?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for beam-total transmittance in terms of beam-diffuse and beam-beam transmittance?
output: \\rm\\tau _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\tau _\\rmbd^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) + \\rm\\tau _\\rmbb^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for off-normal reflectance?
output: \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\rho _\\rmbd^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) + \\left( \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = 9\\rm0^\\circ  \\right) - \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) \\right) \\cdot \\left( 1 - \\rmco\\rms^\\rm0\\rm.6\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for reflectance at 90 degrees?
output: \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm90^\\circ  \\right) = \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) + \\left( \\rm1 - \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) \\right)\\;\\left( \\0.7\\left( \\;\\rm\\rho _^\\rmy \\right)^\\;0.7 \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for apparent yarn reflectance?
output: \\rho ^y = \\frac\\rho_\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right)\\rm1 - \\tau_\\rmbb^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) = \\frac\\rho_\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right)\\rm1 - \\rmA_\\rmo

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: Under what condition are the equations for drapery fabrics used?
output: The equations for drapery fabrics are used subject to the condition that the solar absorptance of the fabric at normal incidence is not less than 1% (ASHRE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for 'b'?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for the off-normal transmittance?
output: \\rm\\tau _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\tau _\\rmbd^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) + \\rm\\tau _\\rmbb^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for the off-normal reflectance?
output: \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\rho _\\rmbd^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) = \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) + \\left( \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = 9\\rm0^\\circ  \\right) - \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) \\right) \\cdot \\left( 1 - \\rmco\\rms^\\rm0\\rm.6\\left( \\rm\\theta  \\right) \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for reflectance at 90 degrees?
output: \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm90^\\circ  \\right) = \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) + \\left( \\rm1 - \\rm\\rho _\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) \\right)\\;\\left( \\0.7\\left( \\;\\rm\\rho _^\\rmy \\right)^\\;0.7 \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> equation
input: What is the equation for the apparent yarn reflectance?
output: \\rho ^y = \\frac\\rho_\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right)\\rm1 - \\tau_\\rmbb^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right) = \\frac\\rho_\\rmbt^\\rmm\\left( \\rm\\theta  = \\rm0 \\right)\\rm1 - \\rmA_\\rmo

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What is the condition for using the set of equations for drapery fabrics?
output: The above set of equations for drapery fabrics are used subject to the condition that the solar absorptance of the fabric at normal incidence is not less than 1\\% (ASHRE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: How are the diffuse-diffuse material properties determined?
output: The diffuse-diffuse material properties for Equivalent layer window model are determined using Rhomberg integration with 32 panels covering the range from $\\theta = 0$ to $\\theta = 90^o$ (ASHRAE 1311-RP).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Daylighting and Window Calculations -> Section: Window Heat Balance Calculation -> text
input: What does the subscript 'X' stand for?
output: The subscript \X\ stands for either front or back side of the layer.
